item.title: Battlefield 6's Season 2 Delay Adds More Challenges, Cosmetics, And Double XP To Season 1
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

As previously announced, Battlefield 6's Season 2 update has been delayed. The developer has now revealed a new update will arrive to extend the current season with added battle pass content, new weekly challenges, and some double XP to tide players over until the new season begins.

The Season 1 extension update to Battlefield 6 and Redsec will arrive on January 20, which is the day the season was originally supposed to conclude, but now players will have new weekly challenges, more time to finish the Season 1 battle pass, and a new Frostfire bonus path to complete.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: 10 Minutes Of Battlefield 6 Season 1 New Maps Gameplay (Blackwell Fields and Eastwood)

The free rewards from the Frostfire bonus path will include a hardware XP boost, a vehicle skin, and player-card customization items, while paid pass owners can grab a new weapon package, a career XP boost, and additional cosmetics. The Frostfire path can also be completed concurrently alongside the Season 1 battle pass. Unlike previous bonus paths, all points for the Frostfire bonus path are earned through new weekly challenges that will be provided.

Battlefield 6 will introduce a new set of daily login rewards and several Double XP weekend events throughout this extended update period. The developer also said the game will celebrate the upcoming Valentine's Day holiday.

Battlefield 6 had a strong start at launch and even outsold Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 in the US through November, but the post-launch content for Season 1 was met with mixed reviews. The third and final phase of content arrived just before the winter holidays, but the update added a host of issues that affected gameplay. This mishap also caused Battlefield 6's $1 million tournament series for Redsec to be postponed.

Battlefield Studios said it will reinforce Battlefield Labs as a public preview for future game updates once they are in the late stages of development. "Both the Season 1 extension and the use of Battlefield Labs will set the foundation for new and exciting content throughout our live seasons, including what will come in Season 2," the developer said.

Season 2 will now begin on February 17, and the developer said new details will be revealed next month. While it's uncertain what changes will be made, the Season 2 update will likely include more maps, guns, and new modes.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Ubisoft Is Sending Out Compensation To Rainbow Six Siege Players Over Hack
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

It was anything but a wonderful holiday season for Ubisoft's Rainbow Six Siege players. Following a massive hack that dumped billions of credits into the community, Ubisoft had to shut down the marketplace and roll back accounts. The fixes aren't entirely in place, but Ubisoft is now offering compensation to its players.

On social media, Ubisoft announced that any Rainbow Six Siege players who log in between January 16-25 will receive the following gifts.

  • 4x battle pass XP
  • Ten battle pass levels
  • Missed daily rewards (Delta Pack, Alpha Pack, Auric Mold skin for the P-10C)

According to Ubisoft's update, account rollbacks are still in progress and the marketplace won't return until a later date in Year 11.

The most common response to this message on X were questions about when the voice chat feature will be restored. Ubisoft replied, "Voice chat continues to be a key priority for the team moving forward."

A separate Rainbow Six Siege X hack occurred earlier this year, which indiscriminately banned players for 67 days in a reference to the 6-7 meme.

Last year, Rainbow Six Siege's transition to Siege X brought a lot of players back to the game a decade after its launch. It's been so successful that creative director Alexander Karpazis told GameSpot there's no immediate reason for Ubisoft to move forward with Rainbow Six Siege 2.

Former Rainbow Six Siege creative director Xavier Marquis recently returned to Ubisoft, but not to the franchise. Instead, Marquis will be working on a new 4v4 tactical multiplayer free-to-play game called March of Giants.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
